results.content:
I think this is one of the bad purchases that I made in Udemy. I have totally enjoyed other courses, but some of the content is just as insulting. 

Before I proceed with the actual review, I phase my progress in this course based on what I need so that could mean why my progress is in the lower end. 

In the project splash page - I do not see the relevance of the heap discussion in the context of the code review section. It seems like it is a "trying hard" discussion to bring a different content on clicking buttons. I feel like this would be the flow just as in other sections so I this one will be most likely will go unfinished. 

However, if you are totally new to JS, I see that it is still a good material but probably for someone looking to add some nice JS functionality in projects, it would be mixed. 

Yes, I am disappointed with this purchase.

results.content:
Ive been taking Andrei's 0 to mastery 2020 class and before that have been on and off with web development. I feel like i'm getting it and then I come to a road block. In the 2020 class I just got to the React section and though I understandcode when I follow along, I often don't know how to attempt on my own. Most classes I've taken teach concept but don't include a lot a practice and random youtube tutorials just don't help me. Before I contiuned on with the React section of the 2020 course I wanted more vanilla JS practice to really understand. This course just so happened to come out right around the time I made it to the React section and I'm so thankful! It really should be suggested to take this course before moving on to a library. I'm only on the 3rd project and I already feel like I have such a better understanding of vanilla JS and will now have all these projects to refrence in the future when I do my own projects. I highly reccomend!

I will also say that I was a bit bummed at first after realizing that Andrei wasn't teaching this course, however I really like Jacinto. Some people you just don't wanna listen too, but Jacinto has a great narrating voice and is really well paced. Not too fast or too slow. I don't have to pause too often and I don't get bored listening to him which can sometimes be a problem for me with tutorials.

Then Andrei came on at the end and there are several commented out comments that were not there in any lecture. I've tried another of Andrei's courses where literally every project did not work, and his chat room, multiple questions asked-no response. I'll continue on but my hopes are very low. Quite annoying, really, and while I realize googling for answers is part of coding, when I have no clue how he generates quotes its very frustrating.

Also, all of the issues you are having (like joining Discord) has not been an issue for any other student.

1) A lot of new areas covered.
2) Many projects were built from scratch.
3) All the aspects were considered in terms of explaining and all the stuff.
4) Very good support in case struck. The response is usually with in 24 hours. 
5) Code review after every project.

Things I think can be improved:
1) Do not speed up the videos.
2) Some projects are not spend enough time explaining. 

But overall a very good course which explains gives a lot of ideas.

results.content: I was so giddy when I saw this course launched a week or so ago.  After taking a couple of Javascript bootcamp courses, I felt like I had a good grasp on the fundamentals, but I was still struggling to implement things into projects and integrate everything together.  My favorite high-beginner/low-intermediate course that helped me take that next step was Brad Traversy's 20 Vanilla JS projects.  I was disappointed when I couldn't find anything similar after I completed it, but then this course came out and I got it right away.  This course gives you so many ideas and tools that you can apply in your own projects and helps you improve your JS skills.  Love it and hope they keep adding new projects from time to time.

After taking a couple of Javascript bootcamp courses, I felt like I had a good grasp on the fundamentals, but I was still struggling to implement things into projects and integrate everything together. My favorite high-beginner/low-intermediate course that helped me take that next step was Brad Traversy's 20 Vanilla JS projects. I was disappointed when I couldn't find anything similar after I completed it, but then this course came out and I got it right away. This course gives you so many ideas and tools that you can apply in your own projects and helps you improve your JS skills. Love it and hope they keep adding new projects from time to time.

results.content:
The projects are impressive, they are explained well, and the senior-dev reviews at the end of each section are valuable. 

It is difficult to get the most out of this course, however, when each project starts from a template instead of from scratch. As a beginner, I *want* to start from the very beginning. It might seem repetitive to more seasoned devs, but I feel like I miss out on a lot of design aspects and programming principles when I'm given starter files.

Good. But the only problem i had with this course is some of the projects were already half finished, and some code already implemented before we even got started. And we only finish it off with some additional code.

I personally like seeing the instructor code it from 0%. From beginning to end. Even the CSS part. This gives me a better understanding of how the overall structure is created. But there's also one thing that I don't really appreciate - the instructor barely tells you why a certain step is needed, but simply lets you follow it through. If you want to build something of your own, it'd not be easy to reconstruct what you've learned from the course - It's easy to pick the dots, but fairly hard to connect the dots to a line. results.content:
I'm torn about how to rate this course.  Jacinto will teach you how to do lots of different things, but if you're intersted in this course to build your portfolio with its projects, that's not what this is.  Jacinto is making the projects, you are just along for the ride. Some of the projects are mostly finished when the lesson begins.

I did all 20 projects and wouldn't put any of them in my portfolio, because they aren't mine.  I would have liked more opportunity to solve the problems myself, if we were given instructions for the next task, pause the video, then have Jacinto show us how he did it.  This is a problem that comes with this kind of short-projects course, and I don't know if any instructor has solved it, so I didn't penalise the rating too much.

If you want to build your portfolio, you need to take some of the ideas and tips that Jacinto teaches you, and go build your own projects with that knowledge.

The projects themselves are of varying interest and quality.  For me, the real gems were the audio and video players, and the drag-and-drop project.  Those were things that I wanted to learn how to do, and now I understand generally how to create them.

results.content:
A nice course. Not too difficult, not too simple. Showed me a couple of new tricks like: 

- svg backgrounds without having to worry about background-position, 
- how to get a favicon from any website, 
- how to do loaders painlessly, 
- an easy way to do light&dark mode 
- and what I especially appreciated was some element positioning practice (I mean stuff like: mouse.clientX, el.offsetTop, window.scrollY things...) as this is something I never feel very confident about.

Thank you very much! The course's great!

If you put up a a sequel I am buying!
